results.question: Chromel is an alloy composed of nickel, iron, and chromium. A 0.6553 - g sample was dissolved and diluted to 250.0 mL. When a 50.00 - mL aliquot of 0.05173 M EDTA was mixed with an equal volume of the diluted sample, all three ions were chelated, and a 5.34 - mL back - titration with 0.06139 M copper(II) was required. The chromium in a second 50.0 - mL aliquot was masked through the addition of hexamethylenetetramine; titration of the Fe and Ni required 36.98 mL of 0.05173 M EDTA. Iron and chromium were masked with pyrophosphate in a third 50.0 - mL aliquot, and the nickel was titrated with 24.53 mL of the EDTA solution. Calculate the percentages of nickel in the alloy.
results.llm_output:
Step 1: Total EDTA consumed by Ni, Fe and Cr in the first aliquot  
• Initial EDTA added:  
  n₁ = (0.05000 L)(0.05173 mol/L) = 0.0025865 mol  
• EDTA left unreacted (back‐titrated by Cu²⁺):  
  n₂ = (0.00534 L)(0.06139 mol/L) = 0.0003278 mol  
• EDTA that reacted with metals:  
  n_EDTA,react = n₁ – n₂ = 0.0025865 – 0.0003278 = 0.0022587 mol  
  ⇒ n_Ni + n_Fe + n_Cr = 0.0022587  (1)  

Step 2: EDTA consumed by Fe + Ni (Cr masked)  
• n_Fe+Ni = (0.03698 L)(0.05173 mol/L) = 0.0019137 mol  
  ⇒ n_Ni + n_Fe = 0.0019137  (2)  

Step 3: EDTA consumed by Ni alone (Fe & Cr masked)  
• n_Ni = (0.02453 L)(0.05173 mol/L) = 0.0012689 mol  (3)  

From (3):  
  Moles of Ni in 50.00 mL aliquot = 0.0012689 mol  
  Moles of Ni in total 250.0 mL = 5 × 0.0012689 = 0.0063445 mol  

Mass of Ni in the sample = (0.0063445 mol)(58.69 g/mol) = 0.3725 g  

% Ni = (0.3725 g Ni / 0.6553 g alloy) × 100% = 56.87%  

Final answer:  
\[
\boxed{56.87}
\]%

results.question: Chromel is an alloy composed of nickel, iron, and chromium. A 0.6553 - g sample was dissolved and diluted to 250.0 mL. When a 50.00 - mL aliquot of 0.05173 M EDTA was mixed with an equal volume of the diluted sample, all three ions were chelated, and a 5.34 - mL back - titration with 0.06139 M copper(II) was required. The chromium in a second 50.0 - mL aliquot was masked through the addition of hexamethylenetetramine; titration of the Fe and Ni required 36.98 mL of 0.05173 M EDTA. Iron and chromium were masked with pyrophosphate in a third 50.0 - mL aliquot, and the nickel was titrated with 24.53 mL of the EDTA solution. Calculate the percentages of chromium in the alloy.
results.llm_output:
Step 1: Moles of EDTA added in the first titration  
n₀ = (0.05000 L)(0.05173 mol L⁻¹) = 0.0025865 mol  

Step 2: Moles of EDTA left (back-titration with Cu²⁺)  
n_back = (0.00534 L)(0.06139 mol L⁻¹) = 0.00032782 mol  

Step 3: Moles of EDTA consumed by Ni²⁺+Fe²⁺+Cr³⁺  
n_total = n₀ – n_back = 0.0025865 – 0.00032782 = 0.00225868 mol  

Step 4: Moles of EDTA in the Fe+Ni titration (aliquot 2)  
n_Fe+Ni = (0.03698 L)(0.05173 mol L⁻¹) = 0.00191298 mol  

Step 5: Moles of EDTA in the Ni titration (aliquot 3)  
n_Ni = (0.02453 L)(0.05173 mol L⁻¹) = 0.00126893 mol  

Step 6: Moles of Fe²⁺ in 50.0 mL  
n_Fe = n_Fe+Ni – n_Ni = 0.00191298 – 0.00126893 = 0.00064405 mol  

Step 7: Moles of Cr³⁺ in 50.0 mL  
n_Cr(50 mL) = n_total – (n_Ni + n_Fe)  
            = 0.00225868 – (0.00126893 + 0.00064405)  
            = 0.00034570 mol  

Step 8: Moles of Cr³⁺ in the whole 250.0 mL sample  
n_Cr(total) = 5 × n_Cr(50 mL) = 5 × 0.00034570 = 0.0017285 mol  

Step 9: Mass of Cr  
m_Cr = (0.0017285 mol)(52.00 g mol⁻¹) = 0.089882 g  

Step 10: Percentage of Cr in the alloy  
%Cr = (0.089882 g / 0.6553 g) × 100 = 13.72  

Final answer:  
\[
\boxed{13.72}
\] %

results.question: A 5.00 - mL sample of brandy was diluted to 1.000 L in a volumetric flask. The ethanol ($\ce{C_2H_5OH}$) in a 25.00 - mL aliquot of the diluted solution was distilled into 50.00 mL of 0.02000 M $\ce{K_2Cr_2O_7}$ and oxidized to acetic acid with heating: $$\ce{3C_2H_5OH + 2Cr_2O_7^{2-} + 16H^+ \to 4Cr^{3+} + 3CH_3COOH + 11H_2O}$$ After cooling, 20.00 mL of 0.1253 M $\ce{Fe^{2+}}$ was pipetted into the flask. The excess $\ce{Fe^{2+}}$ was then titrated with 7.46 mL of the standard $\ce{K_2Cr_2O_7}$ to a diphenylamine sulfonic acid end point. Calculate the percent (w/v) $\ce{C_2H_5OH}$ (46.07 g/mol) in the brandy.
results.llm_output:
Step 1: Moles of \(\ce{Cr2O7^{2-}}\) initially added  
\[
n_{1} = (0.05000\ \mathrm L)(0.02000\ \mathrm M) = 0.0010000\ \mathrm{mol}
\]

Step 2: Moles of \(\ce{Fe^{2+}}\) added  
\[
n_{\rm Fe,\,added} = (0.02000\ \mathrm L)(0.1253\ \mathrm M) = 0.002506\ \mathrm{mol}
\]

Step 3: Moles of \(\ce{Cr2O7^{2-}}\) in the back‐titration  
\[
n_{2} = (0.00746\ \mathrm L)(0.02000\ \mathrm M) = 0.0001492\ \mathrm{mol}
\]
This consumed
\[
6\,n_{2} = 6\times0.0001492 = 0.0008952\ \mathrm{mol\ Fe^{2+}}
\]
so the residual \(\ce{Fe^{2+}}\) after reduction of the remaining dichromate is 0.0008952 mol.

Step 4: Moles of \(\ce{Cr2O7^{2-}}\) reduced by the added \(\ce{Fe^{2+}}\)  
\[
n_{\rm Fe,\,consumed} = 0.002506 - 0.0008952 = 0.0016108\ \mathrm{mol}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
n_{\rm Cr2O7^{2-},\,rem} = \frac{n_{\rm Fe,\,consumed}}{6}
= 0.00026847\ \mathrm{mol}
\]

Step 5: Moles of \(\ce{Cr2O7^{2-}}\) consumed by \(\ce{C2H5OH}\)  
\[
n_{\rm Cr2O7^{2-},\,eth} 
= 0.0010000 - 0.00026847 
= 0.00073153\ \mathrm{mol}
\]

Step 6: Moles of \(\ce{C2H5OH}\) in the 25.00 mL aliquot  
From \(\displaystyle3\,\ce{C2H5OH}+2\,\ce{Cr2O7^{2-}}\to\cdots\),
\[
n_{\rm EtOH,\,aliquot}
= \frac{3}{2}\,n_{\rm Cr2O7^{2-},\,eth}
= 1.5 \times 0.00073153
= 0.0010973\ \mathrm{mol}
\]

Step 7: Concentration in the diluted solution  
\[
[\ce{EtOH}] = \frac{0.0010973}{0.02500\ \mathrm L}
= 0.043892\ \mathrm{M}
\]
In 1.000 L there are 0.043892 mol, i.e.\ 
\[
m_{\ce{EtOH}} = 0.043892\ \mathrm{mol}\times46.07\ \tfrac{\mathrm g}{\mathrm{mol}}
= 2.021\ \mathrm g
\]
This mass came from the original 5.00 mL of brandy, so
\[
\%\,(w/v)
= \frac{2.021\ \mathrm g}{5.00\ \mathrm{mL}}\times100
= 40.4\%\ (w/v)\ \ce{C2H5OH}.
\]

Final answer:
\[
\boxed{40.4}\%\,(w/v)\ \ce{C2H5OH}
\]

\[

=4.857\times10^{-4}\;\mathrm{mol}

\]

results.question: An unknown cadmium(II) solution was analyzed polarographically by the method of standard additions. A 25.00 - mL sample of the unknown solution produced a diffusion current of 1.86 ??A. Following addition of a 5.00 - mL aliquot of \(2.12\times10^{-3}\ \text{M}\ \ce{Cd^{2+}}\) standard solution to the unknown solution, a diffusion current of 5.27 ??A was produced. Calculate the concentration of \(\ce{Cd^{2+}}\) in the unknown solution.
results.llm_output:
Step 1:  By definition of polarographic diffusion current,  
 I ∝ [Cd²⁺],  
so we may write  
 I_u = k C_x  
and  
 I_s = k C_f,  
where  
 C_x = unknown [Cd²⁺],  
 C_s = 2.12×10⁻³ M,  
 V_u = 25.00 mL,  
 V_s = 5.00 mL,  
 V_t = V_u+V_s = 30.00 mL,  
 I_u = 1.86 µA,  
 I_s = 5.27 µA.  

Step 2:  After addition, the final concentration is  
 C_f = (C_x V_u + C_s V_s)/V_t.  

Step 3:  Taking the ratio of currents,  
 I_s/I_u = C_f/C_x = (C_x V_u + C_s V_s)/(V_t C_x)  
 ⇒ I_s/I_u = [V_u + (C_s/C_x)V_s]/V_t.  

Step 4:  Solve for C_x:  
 I_s/I_u = (V_u + V_s C_s/C_x)/V_t  
 ⇒ (I_s/I_u) V_t = V_u + V_s C_s/C_x  
 ⇒ V_s C_s/C_x = (I_s/I_u)V_t − V_u  
 ⇒ C_x = V_s C_s / [ (I_s/I_u)V_t − V_u ].  

Step 5:  Insert numerical values:  
 I_s/I_u = 5.27/1.86 ≈ 2.8333,  
 V_t = 30.00 mL, V_u = 25.00 mL, V_s = 5.00 mL, C_s = 2.12×10⁻³ M,  
so  
 C_x = (5.00 mL)(2.12×10⁻³ M) / [ (2.8333)(30.00 mL) − 25.00 mL ]  
  = 0.01060 mL·M / (85.00 mL − 25.00 mL)  
  = 0.01060 / 60.00  
  = 1.77×10⁻⁴ M.  

Final answer:  
\boxed{1.77\times10^{-4}} M

results.question: Molar absorptivity data for the cobalt and nickel complexes with 2,3 - quinoxalinedithiol are $\varepsilon_{\ce{Co}} = 36,400$ and $\varepsilon_{\ce{Ni}} = 5520$ at 510 nm and $\varepsilon_{\ce{Co}} = 1240$ and $\varepsilon_{\ce{Ni}} = 17,500$ at 656 nm. A 0.425 - g sample was dissolved and diluted to 50.0 mL. A 25.0 - mL aliquot was treated to eliminate interferences; after addition of 2,3 - quinoxalinedithiol, the volume was adjusted to 50.0 mL. This solution had an absorbance of 0.446 at 510 nm and 0.326 at 656 nm in a 1.00 - cm cell. Calculate the concentration in parts per million of cobalt in the sample.
results.llm_output:
Step 1.  Beer’s law at each wavelength gives a system in the unknown molar concentrations $[\ce{Co}]$ and $[\ce{Ni}]$ in the 50.0 mL analysis solution:
\[
A_{510} = \varepsilon_{\ce{Co},510}\,[\ce{Co}] + \varepsilon_{\ce{Ni},510}\,[\ce{Ni}]
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
36400\,[\ce{Co}]+5520\,[\ce{Ni}]=0.446,
\]
\[
A_{656} = \varepsilon_{\ce{Co},656}\,[\ce{Co}] + \varepsilon_{\ce{Ni},656}\,[\ce{Ni}]
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
1240\,[\ce{Co}]+17500\,[\ce{Ni}]=0.326.
\]

Step 2.  Solve by Cramer’s rule for $[\ce{Co}]$:
\[
[\ce{Co}]
=\frac{
\begin{vmatrix}
0.446 & 5520\\
0.326 &17500
\end{vmatrix}
}{
\begin{vmatrix}
36400 & 5520\\
1240  &17500
\end{vmatrix}
}
=\frac{0.446\cdot17500-0.326\cdot5520}{36400\cdot17500-5520\cdot1240}
=\frac{6005.48}{6.301552\times10^8}
=9.5328\times10^{-6}\ \mathrm{M}.
\]

\[
n_{\ce{Co},\mathrm{aliquot}}
=[\ce{Co}]\times0.0500\ \mathrm{L}
=9.5328\times10^{-6}\times0.0500
=4.7664\times10^{-7}\ \mathrm{mol}.
\]
Hence moles in the original 50.0 mL sample is twice that,
\[
n_{\ce{Co},\mathrm{sample}}
=9.5328\times10^{-7}\ \mathrm{mol}.
\]

Step 4.  Mass of Co in the 0.425 g sample:
\[
m_{\ce{Co}}
=n_{\ce{Co},\mathrm{sample}}\times M_{\ce{Co}}
=9.5328\times10^{-7}\times58.93
=5.6145\times10^{-5}\ \mathrm{g}.
\]

Step 5.  Convert to ppm (mg Co per kg sample):
\[
\mathrm{Co(ppm)}
=\frac{m_{\ce{Co}}/\,\mathrm{g}}{m_{\text{sample}}/\,\mathrm{g}}\times10^6
=\frac{5.6145\times10^{-5}}{0.425}\times10^6
=132.1.
\]

Final answer:
\[
\boxed{132.1}\ \mathrm{Co(ppm)}
\]

results.question: Molar absorptivity data for the cobalt and nickel complexes with 2,3 - quinoxalinedithiol are $\varepsilon_{\ce{Co}} = 36,400$ and $\varepsilon_{\ce{Ni}} = 5520$ at 510 nm and $\varepsilon_{\ce{Co}} = 1240$ and $\varepsilon_{\ce{Ni}} = 17,500$ at 656 nm. A 0.425 - g sample was dissolved and diluted to 50.0 mL. A 25.0 - mL aliquot was treated to eliminate interferences; after addition of 2,3 - quinoxalinedithiol, the volume was adjusted to 50.0 mL. This solution had an absorbance of 0.446 at 510 nm and 0.326 at 656 nm in a 1.00 - cm cell. Calculate the concentration in parts per million of nickel in the sample.
results.llm_output:
Step 1.  Write the Beer–Lambert equations at 510 nm and 656 nm (pathlength b=1.00 cm):  
A₅₁₀ = ε₅₁₀,Co·[Co]·b + ε₅₁₀,Ni·[Ni]·b  
A₆₅₆ = ε₆₅₆,Co·[Co]·b + ε₆₅₆,Ni·[Ni]·b  

Numerical values:  
ε₅₁₀,Co=36400 L mol⁻¹ cm⁻¹,  ε₅₁₀,Ni=5520 L mol⁻¹ cm⁻¹,  A₅₁₀=0.446  
ε₆₅₆,Co=1240 L mol⁻¹ cm⁻¹,   ε₆₅₆,Ni=17500 L mol⁻¹ cm⁻¹, A₆₅₆=0.326  

So  
(1) 36400·[Co] +  5520·[Ni] = 0.446  
(2)  1240·[Co] + 17500·[Ni] = 0.326  

Step 2.  Solve for [Ni].  From (1):  
[Co] = (0.446 − 5520[Ni]) / 36400.  
Substitute into (2):  
1240·(0.446−5520[Ni])/36400 + 17500[Ni] = 0.326  
⇒ 0.01519 − 188.044[Ni] + 17500[Ni] = 0.326  
⇒ 17311.956[Ni] = 0.31081  
⇒ [Ni] = 1.7959×10⁻⁵ M.  

Step 3.  Moles of Ni in the 50.0 mL final solution:  
n(Ni) = [Ni]·V = (1.7959×10⁻⁵ mol L⁻¹)(0.0500 L) = 8.9796×10⁻⁷ mol.  

This 50.0 mL comes from a 25.0 mL aliquot of the original sample (which weighed 0.425 g in 50.0 mL).  Thus the aliquot contains half the sample mass.  The total moles of Ni in the entire 0.425 g sample is twice this:  
n_total(Ni) = 2·8.9796×10⁻⁷ mol = 1.7959×10⁻⁶ mol.  

Step 4.  Mass of Ni in the 0.425 g sample (M(Ni)=58.69 g mol⁻¹):  
m(Ni) = n_total(Ni)·M(Ni) = (1.7959×10⁻⁶ mol)(58.69 g mol⁻¹) = 1.0545×10⁻⁴ g.  

Step 5.  Nickel concentration in ppm (mg Ni per kg sample ≃ g Ni per g sample ×10⁶):  
Ni(ppm) = [m(Ni)/0.425 g]·10⁶ = (1.0545×10⁻⁴ g / 0.425 g)·10⁶ = 2.4817×10².  

Final answer:  
\boxed{248} Ni(ppm)

Question: """Given that the average molar mass of the polymer chains in this sample of poly(lactic acid) (PLA) is \pu{595 g mol^{-1}} using end-group analysis, where \pu{0.1619 g} of PLA was dissolved in \pu{25 cm^3} of benzyl alcohol and titrated with \pu{0.0400 mol dm^{-3}} \ce{KOH} solution. Model's reasoning: """Step 1: Molar mass of the lactic‐acid repeat unit (–CH(CH₃)–CO–O–)  
\[

= 3\times12.01 + 4\times1.008 + 2\times16.00

\]

Step 2: Degree of polymerization \(n\)  
\[
n \;=\;\frac{M_n}{M_{\rm repeat}}
\;=\;\frac{595\;\mathrm{g\,mol^{-1}}}{72.06\;\mathrm{g\,mol^{-1}}}
\approx 8.26
\]

Final answer:  
\[
\boxed{8.26}
\]"""

Model's final answer: 8.26

results.question: Poly(lactic acid) (PLA) can be broken down enzymatically to lactic acid monomer and compound B (a dimer of lactic acid). A plastic sample degraded to \pu{1.044 g}, and titration showed it needed \pu{19.40 cm^3} of \pu{0.100 mol dm^{-3}} \ce{NaOH} to neutralize. What is the number of moles of acid in the sample?
results.llm_output:
Step 1: Convert titrant volume to dm³  
\(V = 19.40\text{ cm}^3 = 19.40\times10^{-3}\text{ dm}^3\)

Step 2: Calculate moles of NaOH added  
\[
n(\ce{NaOH})
= c \times V
= 0.100\ \mathrm{mol\,dm^{-3}}\times 19.40\times10^{-3}\ \mathrm{dm^3}
= 1.94\times10^{-3}\ \mathrm{mol}
\]

Step 3: Relate moles of NaOH to moles of acid groups  
Each acid group consumes one mole of NaOH, so  
\[
n(\text{acid}) = n(\ce{NaOH}) = 1.94\times10^{-3}\ \mathrm{mol}
\]

Final answer:
\[
\boxed{1.94\times10^{-3}}\ \mathrm{mol}
\]

results.question: How can you determine the average molar mass of polymer chains in a sample of poly(lactic acid) (PLA) using end-group analysis? In this procedure, \pu{0.1619 g} of PLA was dissolved in \pu{25 cm^3} of benzyl alcohol, and the mixture was titrated with \pu{0.0400 mol dm^{-3}} \ce{KOH} solution. The volume of \ce{KOH} solution required to reach the endpoint was \pu{6.81 cm^3}. What is the average molar mass of the polymer chains in the sample of PLA (in \pu{g mol^{-1}})?
results.llm_output:
Step‐by‐step solution:

1.  Each PLA chain bears one carboxylic acid end‐group.  Titration with KOH therefore measures the number of chains.

2.  Moles of KOH at the endpoint:
   \(n_{\mathrm{KOH}} = c\times V
     = (0.0400\;\mathrm{mol\,dm^{-3}})\times(6.81\;\mathrm{cm^3}\times10^{-3}\,\mathrm{dm^3/cm^3})
     = 2.724\times10^{-4}\;\mathrm{mol}.\)

3.  Number of polymer chains \(=\) moles of acid end‐groups \(=\) \(2.724\times10^{-4}\) mol.

4.  Average molar mass:
   \[
     M_n \;=\;\frac{\text{mass of PLA}}{\text{number of chains}}
     \;=\;\frac{0.1619\;\mathrm{g}}{2.724\times10^{-4}\;\mathrm{mol}}
     \;=\;5.94\times10^2\;\mathrm{g\,mol^{-1}}.
   \]

Final answer:
\[
\boxed{5.94\times10^2}\;\mathrm{g\,mol^{-1}}
\]

results.question: Gold atom crystallizes in a cubic arrangement such that it occupies all the corners and all the center of the faces. What fraction of the volume of the unit cell is occupied by gold atoms?
results.llm_output:
Step 1: Count of atoms per unit cell  
– Corner atoms: 8 × (1/8) = 1  
– Face‐center atoms: 6 × (1/2) = 3  
⇒ Total = 4 atoms  

Step 2: Relation between edge length a and atomic radius r  
In an f.c.c. lattice the face diagonal passes through two radii from corner atoms and two radii from the face‐center atom:  
face diagonal = a√2 = 4r  
⇒ a = (4r)/√2 = 2√2 r  

Step 3: Volumes  
– Volume of unit cell:  
  Vcell = a^3 = (2√2 r)^3 = 16√2 r^3  
– Total volume of 4 atoms (each a sphere of radius r):  
  Vatoms = 4 × (4/3)πr^3 = (16/3)πr^3  

Step 4: Packing fraction  
  η = Vatoms / Vcell  
    = [(16/3)πr^3] / [16√2 r^3]  
    = π/(3√2)  

Final answer:  
\[
\boxed{\frac{\pi}{3\sqrt{2}}}
\]

results.question: The calculated spin only magnetic moments of $\left[\mathrm{Cr}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{6}\right]^{3+}$ is ? (Atomic numbers of $\mathrm{Cr}$ is 24)
results.llm_output:
Step 1: Oxidation state of Cr in \([\mathrm{Cr(NH_3)_6}]^{3+}\) is +3 (NH₃ is neutral).

Step 2: Cr(III) has electronic configuration \(\mathrm{[Ar]\,3d^3}\). Thus the number of unpaired electrons is \(n=3\).

Step 3: The spin‐only magnetic moment is given by
\[
\mu = \sqrt{n(n+2)}\;\mu_B = \sqrt{3(3+2)}\;\mu_B = \sqrt{15}\;\mu_B \approx 3.87\;\mu_B.
\]

Final answer:
\[
\boxed{3.87}\,\mu_B
\]

results.question: The calculated spin only magnetic moments of $\left[\mathrm{CuF}_{6}\right]^{3-}$ in $\mathrm{BM}$ is ? (Atomic numbers of $\mathrm{Cu} is 29)
results.llm_output:
Step 1: Oxidation state of Cu in \([\mathrm{CuF}_{6}]^{3-}\)  
Let \(x\) = oxidation state of Cu. Then  
\(x + 6(-1) = -3 \implies x = +3\).  

Step 2: d‐electron count for Cu³⁺  
Neutral Cu is [Ar] 3d¹⁰ 4s¹. Removing 3 e⁻ gives Cu³⁺: 3d⁸.  

Step 3: High‐spin vs. low‐spin  
Fluoride is a weak field ligand ⇒ high‐spin configuration. For d⁸ in octahedral field:  
t₂g⁶ e_g² ⇒ 2 unpaired electrons.  

Step 4: Spin‐only magnetic moment  
Number of unpaired electrons \(n=2\).  
\(\displaystyle \mu_{\rm s\,only} = \sqrt{n(n+2)}\;{\rm BM} 
= \sqrt{2(2+2)} 
= \sqrt{8} 
\approx 2.83\;{\rm BM}.\)  

Final Answer:  
\(\displaystyle \boxed{2.83}\rm\,BM\)

results.question:
2 mol of $\mathrm{Hg}(g)$ is combusted in a fixed volume bomb calorimeter with excess of $\mathrm{O}_{2}$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}$ and 1 atm into $\mathrm{HgO}(s)$. During the reaction, temperature increases from $298.0 \mathrm{~K}$ to $312.8 \mathrm{~K}$. If heat capacity of the bomb calorimeter and enthalpy of formation of $\mathrm{Hg}(g)$ are $20.00 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}$ and $61.32 \mathrm{~kJ}$ $\mathrm{mol}^{-1}$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}$, respectively, the calculated standard molar enthalpy of formation of $\mathrm{HgO}(s)$ at 298 $\mathrm{K}$ is $\mathrm{X} \mathrm{kJ} \mathrm{mol} \mathrm{m}^{-1}$. What is the value of $|\mathrm{X}|$?

[Given: Gas constant $\mathrm{R}=8.3 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ ]
results.llm_output:
Step 1.  Heat absorbed by the calorimeter  
\[
q_{\rm cal} \;=\; C_{\rm cal}\,\Delta T
\;=\;(20.00\;\mathrm{kJ/K})\,(312.8-298.0)\;\mathrm K
\;=\;296.0\;\mathrm{kJ}.
\]  
Since the reaction is exothermic and the calorimeter absorbs this heat,
\[
q_{\rm rxn,\;V}
\;=\;-\,q_{\rm cal}
\;=\;-296.0\;\mathrm{kJ},
\]
for the reaction
\[
2\,\mathrm{Hg}(g)\;+\;\mathrm O_2(g)\;\longrightarrow\;2\,\mathrm{HgO}(s).
\]

Step 2.  Convert ΔE to ΔH  
At constant volume  
\[
\Delta H
=\Delta E + \Delta n_{\rm gas}\,R\,T,
\]
here \(\Delta n_{\rm gas}=0-3=-3\), \(T=298.15\) K and \(R=8.314\) J K\(^{-1}\) mol\(^{-1}\):  
\[
\Delta H_{\rm rxn}
=-296.0\;\mathrm{kJ}
+(-3)(8.314\;\mathrm{J/K/mol})(298.15\;\mathrm K)
=-296.0\;\mathrm{kJ}-7.43\;\mathrm{kJ}
=-303.43\;\mathrm{kJ}
\]
for 2 mol of Hg.

Hence per mole of HgO formed,
\[
\Delta H
=\frac{-303.43\;\mathrm{kJ}}{2}
=-151.715\;\mathrm{kJ}
\]
for the reaction
\[
\mathrm{Hg}(g)+\tfrac12\,\mathrm O_2(g)\longrightarrow\mathrm{HgO}(s).
\]

Step 3.  Convert from Hg(g) to elemental Hg(l)  
By definition
\(\Delta H_f^\circ[\mathrm{Hg}(g)]=+61.32\;\mathrm{kJ/mol}\) for
\(\mathrm{Hg}(l)\to\mathrm{Hg}(g)\).
Thus
\[
\Delta H_f^\circ[\mathrm{HgO}(s)]
=\Delta H(\mathrm{Hg}(l)\to\mathrm{Hg}(g))
+\Delta H(\mathrm{Hg}(g)+\tfrac12\,\mathrm O_2\to\mathrm{HgO}(s))
=+61.32\;-\;151.715
=-90.395\;\mathrm{kJ/mol}.
\]

Therefore,
\[
|X| = 90.4\;\mathrm{kJ/mol}.
\]  
\[
\boxed{90.4}\;\mathrm{kJ\,mol^{-1}}
\]

results.question: Find an expression for the change in entropy when two blocks of the same substance and of equal mass, one at the temperature $T_\text{h}$ and the other at $T_\text{c}$, are brought into thermal contact and allowed to reach equilibrium. Evaluate the change in entropy for two blocks of copper, each of mass 500 g, with $C_{p,\text{m}} = 24.4\ \text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}$, taking $T_\text{h} = 500\ \text{K}$ and $T_\text{c} = 250\ \text{K}$.
results.llm_output:
Solution:

Let each block have mass m and molar heat capacity \(C_{p,m}\). The number of moles is
\[
n = \frac{m}{M},
\]
where \(M\) is the molar mass.  When the two blocks, initially at \(T_h\) and \(T_c\), come to equilibrium at
\[
T_{\rm eq} = \frac{T_h + T_c}{2},
\]
the total change of entropy is the sum of the entropy changes of each block:
\[
\Delta S
= n\,C_{p,m}\ln\frac{T_{\rm eq}}{T_c}
+ n\,C_{p,m}\ln\frac{T_{\rm eq}}{T_h}
= n\,C_{p,m}\ln\frac{T_{\rm eq}^2}{T_h\,T_c}.
\]

For copper, \(M=63.546\ \mathrm{g/mol}\), \(C_{p,m}=24.4\ \mathrm{J\,K^{-1}mol^{-1}}\), and \(m=500\ \mathrm g\), so
\[
n = \frac{500}{63.546}\approx7.873\ {\rm mol}, 
\quad
T_{\rm eq}=\frac{500+250}{2}=375\ {\rm K}.
\]
Thus
\[
\Delta S
= (7.873)(24.4)\,\ln\!\biggl(\frac{375^2}{500\cdot250}\biggr)
\approx22.6\ \mathrm{J/K}.
\]

Final numerical result:
\[
\boxed{22.6}
\ \mathrm{J/K}
\]

results.question: The standard enthalpy of combustion of liquid ethyl ethanoate (ethyl acetate, $\ce{CH_3COOC_2H_5}$) is $-2231\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}$ at $298\ \text{K}$ and its standard molar entropy is $259.4\ \text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}$. Calculate the standard Gibbs energy of formation of the compound at $298\ \text{K}$.
results.llm_output:
Step 1: Write the combustion reaction and its enthalpy  
\[
\ce{CH3COOC2H5(l) + 5 O2(g) -> 4 CO2(g) + 4 H2O(l)}, 
\quad \Delta H^\circ_{\rm c} = -2231\;\mathrm{kJ/mol}.
\]

Step 2: Use standard enthalpies of formation  
\[
\Delta H^\circ_{\rm c}
=\sum \Delta H^\circ_{\rm f}(\text{products})
-\Delta H^\circ_{\rm f}(\text{reactants})
=4\Delta H^\circ_{\rm f}(\ce{CO2})+4\Delta H^\circ_{\rm f}(\ce{H2O})
-\Delta H^\circ_{\rm f}(\ce{EA}),
\]
so
\[
-2231
=4(-393.5)+4(-285.83)-\Delta H^\circ_{\rm f}(\ce{EA}),
\]
\[
\Delta H^\circ_{\rm f}(\ce{EA})
=4(-393.5)+4(-285.83)+2231
=-486.3\;\mathrm{kJ/mol}.
\]

Step 3: Compute the standard entropy change for the formation reaction  
\[
4\,\ce C(\text{gr})+4\,\ce H2(g)+\ce O2(g)\to\ce{CH3COOC2H5(l)},
\]
using \(S^\circ(\ce{EA})=259.4\)\,J K\(^{-1}\) mol\(^{-1}\),
\(S^\circ(\ce{C,gr})=5.74\), 
\(S^\circ(\ce{H2})=130.68\), 
\(S^\circ(\ce{O2})=205.15\)\,J K\(^{-1}\) mol\(^{-1}\):
\[
\Delta S^\circ_{\rm f}
=259.4 -[4\times5.74 +4\times130.68 +205.15]
=-491.4\;\mathrm{J\,K^{-1}\,mol^{-1}}
=-0.4914\;\mathrm{kJ\,K^{-1}\,mol^{-1}}.
\]

Step 4: Compute \(\Delta G^\circ_{\rm f}=\Delta H^\circ_{\rm f}-T\Delta S^\circ_{\rm f}\) at \(T=298\) K  
\[
\Delta G^\circ_{\rm f}(\ce{EA})
=-486.3 - (298)(-0.4914)
=-486.3 +146.4
=-339.9\;\mathrm{kJ/mol}.
\]

Final answer:
\[
\boxed{-339.9}
\]\;kJ mol\(^{-1}\)

results.question: Estimate the change in the Gibbs energy of $1.0\ \text{dm}^3$ of liquid octane when the pressure acting on it is increased from $1.0\ \text{atm}$ to $100\ \text{atm}$. Given that the mass density of octane is $0.703\ \text{g cm}^{-3}$, determine the change in the molar Gibbs energy.  Retain one decimal place, and the unit is $\text{kJ¡¤mol}^{-1}$.
results.llm_output:
Step 1:  ΔG for compressing a liquid from \(P_1\) to \(P_2\) at constant volume is  
\[
\Delta G \;=\;\int_{P_1}^{P_2}V\,dP \;\approx\; V\,(P_2 - P_1).
\]

Step 2:  Determine the molar volume \(V_m\).  The molar mass of octane (\(\mathrm{C_8H_{18}}\)) is  
\[
M = 8\times12.011 + 18\times1.008 = 114.23\ \mathrm{g\,mol^{-1}},
\]  
and its density is \(\rho=0.703\ \mathrm{g\,cm^{-3}}\).  Thus  
\[
V_m = \frac{M}{\rho}
      = \frac{114.23\ \mathrm{g\,mol^{-1}}}{0.703\ \mathrm{g\,cm^{-3}}}
      = 162.5\ \mathrm{cm^3\,mol^{-1}}
      = 1.625\times10^{-4}\ \mathrm{m^3\,mol^{-1}}.
\]

Step 3:  Pressure change  
\[
\Delta P = P_2 - P_1 = (100 - 1)\ \mathrm{atm} = 99\ \mathrm{atm}
          = 99\times1.01325\times10^5\ \mathrm{Pa}
          = 1.0031\times10^7\ \mathrm{Pa}.
\]

Step 4:  Molar Gibbs‐energy change  
\[
\Delta G_m = V_m\,\Delta P
           = (1.625\times10^{-4}\ \mathrm{m^3\,mol^{-1}})
             \,(1.0031\times10^7\ \mathrm{Pa})
           = 1.630\times10^3\ \mathrm{J\,mol^{-1}}
           = 1.63\ \mathrm{kJ\,mol^{-1}}
           \approx 1.6\ \mathrm{kJ\,mol^{-1}}.
\]

Final answer:  
\[
\boxed{1.6}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

          = 1.0031\times10^7\ \mathrm{Pa}.
\]

Step 4:  Molar Gibbs‐energy change  
\[
\Delta G_m = V_m\,\Delta P
           = (1.625\times10^{-4}\ \mathrm{m^3\,mol^{-1}})
             \,(1.0031\times10^7\ \mathrm{Pa})
           = 1.630\times10^3\ \mathrm{J\,mol^{-1}}
           = 1.63\ \mathrm{kJ\,mol^{-1}}
           \approx 1.6\ \mathrm{kJ\,mol^{-1}}.
\]

Final answer:  
\[
\boxed{1.6}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]"""

Model's final answer: 1.6

Correct answer: 1.6

Judgement:

results.question: Imagine the vaporization of $1\ \text{mol}\ \ce{H_2O(l)}$ at the normal boiling point and against $1\ \text{atm}$ external pressure. Calculate the work done by the water vapour and hence what fraction of the enthalpy of vaporization is spent on expanding the vapour. The enthalpy of vaporization of water is $40.7\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}$ at the normal boiling point.
results.llm_output:
Step 1.  Compute the volume change on vaporization (liquid volume ≪ gas volume):  
\[
\Delta V \approx V_{\rm g} 
= \frac{RT_b}{P}
= \frac{(8.3145\;\mathrm{J\,mol^{-1}K^{-1}})(373.15\;\mathrm{K})}{1.01325\times10^5\;\mathrm{Pa}}
=0.03062\;\mathrm{m^3/mol}.
\]

Step 2.  Work done by the vapor against 1 atm:  
\[
w = P\,\Delta V
= (1.01325\times10^5\;\mathrm{Pa})(0.03062\;\mathrm{m^3})
=3.10\times10^3\;\mathrm{J}
=3.10\;\mathrm{kJ}.
\]

Step 3.  Fraction of ΔHvap spent on expansion:  
\[
\frac{w}{\Delta H_{\rm vap}}\times100\%
=\frac{3.10\;\mathrm{kJ}}{40.7\;\mathrm{kJ}}\times100\%
=7.62\%.
\]

Final answer:  
\[
\boxed{7.62}\%
\]

results.question: The partial molar volumes of propanone (acetone) and trichloromethane (chloroform) in a mixture in which the mole fraction of $\ce{CHCl_3}$ is $0.4693$ are $74.166\ \text{cm}^3\text{mol}^{-1}$ and $80.235\ \text{cm}^3\text{mol}^{-1}$, respectively. What is the volume of a solution of mass $1.000\ \text{kg}$?
results.llm_output:
Step 1 Molar masses  
\[
M_{\rm acetone} = 3(12.011)+6(1.00794)+15.9994 = 58.0800\ {\rm g/mol},\quad
M_{\rm CHCl_3} = 12.011+1.00794+3(35.453)=119.378\ {\rm g/mol}.
\]

Step 2 Average molar mass of the mixture  
\[
\bar M = x_{\rm acetone}M_{\rm acetone}+x_{\rm CHCl_3}M_{\rm CHCl_3}
=(0.5307)(58.0800)+(0.4693)(119.378)=86.8472\ {\rm g/mol}.
\]

Step 3 Total moles in 1000 g  
\[
N=\frac{1000\ {\rm g}}{\bar M}= \frac{1000}{86.8472}=11.515\ {\rm mol}.
\]

Step 4 Moles of each component  
\[
n_{\rm acetone}=x_{\rm acetone}\,N=0.5307\cdot11.515=6.112\ {\rm mol},\quad
n_{\rm CHCl_3}=0.4693\cdot11.515=5.403\ {\rm mol}.
\]

Step 5 Total volume via partial molar volumes  
\[
V=n_{\rm acetone}\,\bar V_{\rm acetone}+n_{\rm CHCl_3}\,\bar V_{\rm CHCl_3}
=6.112(74.166)+5.403(80.235)=886.8\ {\rm cm^3}.
\]

Final Answer:  
\[
\boxed{886.8}\ \text{cm}^3
\]

results.question: The excess Gibbs energy of solutions of methylcyclohexane (MCH) and tetrahydrofuran (THF) at $303.15\ \text{K}$ were found to fit the expression   $$G^\text{E} = RTx(1 - x)\{0.4857 - 0.1077(2x - 1) + 0.0191(2x - 1)^2\}$$   where $x$ is the mole fraction of MCH. Calculate the Gibbs energy of mixing when a mixture of $1.00\ \text{mol}$ MCH and $3.00\ \text{mol}$ THF is prepared.
results.llm_output:
Step 1: Compute mole fractions  
\[
n_{\rm MCH}=1.00,\quad n_{\rm THF}=3.00,\quad n_{\rm tot}=4.00
\]  
\[
x\equiv x_{\rm MCH}=\frac{1.00}{4.00}=0.25,\qquad1-x=0.75
\]

Step 2: Evaluate the excess‐Gibbs energy per mole, \(G^E\)  
\[
2x-1=2(0.25)-1=-0.5,\quad(2x-1)^2=0.25
\]  
\[
\bigl\{\,\cdots\bigr\}
=0.4857-0.1077(-0.5)+0.0191(0.25)=0.544325
\]  
\[
x(1-x)=0.25\times0.75=0.1875
\]  
\[
RT=8.314\;\tfrac{\rm J}{\rm mol\,K}\times303.15\;\rm K=2520.4\;\tfrac{\rm J}{\rm mol}
\]  
\[
G^E=RT\,x(1-x)\{\,\cdots\}
=2520.4\times0.1875\times0.544325
\approx257.2\;\tfrac{\rm J}{\rm mol}
\]

Step 3: Evaluate the ideal‐mixing term per mole  
\[
\Delta G_{\rm mix}^{\rm id}=RT\bigl[x\ln x+(1-x)\ln(1-x)\bigr]
\]
\[
x\ln x+(1-x)\ln(1-x)
=0.25\ln0.25+0.75\ln0.75=-0.562334
\]
\[
\Delta G_{\rm mix}^{\rm id}
=2520.4\times(-0.562334)
\approx-1416.3\;\tfrac{\rm J}{\rm mol}
\]

Step 4: Total Gibbs energy of mixing per mole  
\[
\Delta \bar G_{\rm mix}
=\Delta G_{\rm mix}^{\rm id}+G^E
=-1416.3+257.2=-1159.1\;\tfrac{\rm J}{\rm mol}
\]

Step 5: Total Gibbs energy of mixing for 4 mol of mixture  
\[
\Delta G_{\rm mix}=n_{\rm tot}\,\Delta \bar G_{\rm mix}
=4.00\times(-1159.1\;\tfrac{\rm J}{\rm mol})
=-4636.4\;\rm J
=-4.64\;\rm kJ
\]

Final answer:  
\[
\boxed{-4.64}\ \text{kJ}
\]

results.question: The standard Gibbs energy of formation of \ce{NH_3(g)} is -16.5\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1} at 298\ \text{K}. What is the corresponding reaction Gibbs energy when the partial pressures of the \ce{N_2}, \ce{H_2}, and \ce{NH_3} (treated as perfect gases) are 3.0\ \text{bar}, 1.0\ \text{bar}, and 4.0\ \text{bar}, respectively? What is the spontaneous direction of the reaction in this case? Round the result to an integer.
results.llm_output:
Step 1: Write the formation reaction of NH₃(g) from its elements  
\[
\tfrac12\mathrm{N_2}(g)\;+\;\tfrac32\mathrm{H_2}(g)\;\longrightarrow\;\mathrm{NH_3}(g)
\]

Step 2: Write ΔG at non‐standard conditions  
\[
\Delta G \;=\;\Delta G^\circ\;+\;RT\ln Q
\]
with  
\[
Q \;=\;\frac{p_{\rm NH_3}}{(p_{\rm N_2})^{1/2}\,(p_{\rm H_2})^{3/2}}
\]

Step 3: Compute \(Q\)  
\[
Q = \frac{4.0}{(3.0)^{1/2}\,(1.0)^{3/2}}
= \frac{4.0}{\sqrt{3.0}}
\approx 2.309
\]

Step 4: Compute \(RT\ln Q\) at \(T=298\) K  
\[
RT = (8.314\;\mathrm{J\,mol^{-1}K^{-1}})(298\;\mathrm K)
=2.478\;\mathrm{kJ\,mol^{-1}}
\]
\[
RT\ln Q = 2.478\;\mathrm{kJ/mol}\times\ln(2.309)
\approx 2.07\;\mathrm{kJ\,mol^{-1}}
\]

Step 5: Compute \(\Delta G\)  
\[
\Delta G = \Delta G^\circ + RT\ln Q
= (-16.5) + (2.07)
= -14.43\;\mathrm{kJ\,mol^{-1}}
\]
Rounded to an integer: \(-14\;\mathrm{kJ\,mol^{-1}}\).

Since \(\Delta G<0\), the reaction proceeds spontaneously in the forward direction (toward NH₃ formation).

Final answer:  
\[
\boxed{-14}\ \mathrm{kJ\,mol^{-1}}
\]  
Spontaneous direction: forward (toward NH₃).

results.question: The equilibrium pressure of \ce{H_2} over \ce{U(s)} and \ce{UH_3(s)} between 450\ \text{K} and 715\ \text{K} fits the expression \ln(p/\text{Pa}) = A + B/T + C \ln(T/\text{K}), with A = 69.32, B = -1.464 \times 10^4\ \text{K}, and C = -5.65. Find an expression for the standard enthalpy of formation of \ce{UH_3(s)} and from it calculate \Delta_rC_{p}^{\ominus}. Requirement: Round the results to one decimal place.
results.llm_output:
Below is the derivation of the standard enthalpy of formation of UH₃(s) and the resulting reaction heat–capacity change.

1.  Equilibrium for  
     U(s) + ³⁄₂ H₂(g) ⇌ UH₃(s)  
    gives  
     Kₚ = p_H₂^(–3/2) ⇒ ln Kₚ = –(3/2) ln p  
    with ln p = A + B/T + C ln T.  

2.  Van’t Hoff relation:  
     Δ_rH°(T) = R T² (d ln Kₚ / dT)  
    ⇒ ln Kₚ = –(3/2)(A + B/T + C ln T)  
    ⇒ d ln Kₚ/dT = (3B)/(2T²) – (3C)/(2T)  
    ⇒ Δ_rH°(T) = R T²[(3B)/(2T²) – (3C)/(2T)]  
                 = (3R/2)(B – C T).  

3.  Hence the standard enthalpy of formation is  
    \[
      \Delta_{f}H^\circ\bigl[\mathrm{UH_3},T\bigr]
      \;=\;\frac{3R}{2}\,\bigl(B - C\,T\bigr)
      \;=\;\frac{3\cdot8.314}{2}\,\bigl(-1.464\times10^4 +5.65\,T\bigr)
      \;=\;-1.8256\times10^5 +70.5\,T
      \;\bigl[\mathrm{J\,mol^{-1}}\bigr].
    \]

4.  The reaction heat capacity is  
    \[
      \Delta_{r}C_p^\circ
      \;=\;\frac{d\,\Delta_{r}H^\circ}{dT}
      \;=\;-\,\frac{3R\,C}{2}
      \;=\;70.5\;\mathrm{J\,K^{-1}\,mol^{-1}}.
    \]

Final numerical answer:
\[
  \boxed{70.5}\;\mathrm{J\,K^{-1}\,mol^{-1}}
\]

results.question: Suppose that the junction between two semiconductors can be represented by a barrier of height 2.0 eV and length 100 pm. Calculate the transmission probability of an electron with energy 1.5 eV.
results.llm_output:
Step 1.  Barrier parameters and electron energy  
 Barrier height: \(V_{0}=2.0\;\mathrm{eV}\)  
 Barrier width: \(a=100\;\mathrm{pm}=1.00\times10^{-10}\,\mathrm{m}\)  
 Electron energy: \(E=1.5\;\mathrm{eV}\)  
 Define \(\Delta V=V_{0}-E=0.5\;\mathrm{eV}=0.5\times1.602\times10^{-19}\,\mathrm{J}=8.01\times10^{-20}\,\mathrm{J}.\)

Step 2.  Decay constant inside the barrier  
\[
\kappa=\frac{\sqrt{2m\,(V_{0}-E)}}{\hbar}
=\frac{\sqrt{2\,(9.109\times10^{-31}\,\mathrm{kg})\,(8.01\times10^{-20}\,\mathrm{J})}}{1.0546\times10^{-34}\,\mathrm{J\,s}}
\approx3.63\times10^{9}\,\mathrm{m^{-1}}.
\]

Step 3.  Exact transmission probability for a rectangular barrier  
For \(E<V_{0}\),
\[
T \;=\;\frac{1}{1+\displaystyle\frac{V_{0}^{2}\,\sinh^{2}(\kappa a)}{4\,E\,(V_{0}-E)}}.
\]
Here
\(\kappa a\approx3.63\times10^{9}\,\mathrm{m^{-1}}\times1.00\times10^{-10}\,\mathrm{m}=0.3625\),  
\(\sinh(0.3625)\approx0.3705\),  
so  
\[
\frac{V_{0}^{2}\,\sinh^{2}(\kappa a)}{4\,E\,(V_{0}-E)}
=\frac{(2.0)^{2}\,(0.3705)^{2}}{4\,(1.5)\,(0.5)}
\approx0.1831,
\]
and
\[
T=\frac{1}{1+0.1831}\approx0.845.
\]

Final answer:  
\[
\boxed{0.845}
\]

results.question: Calculate the corresponding rotational constant of an $\ce{^{16}O3}$ molecule given the moment of inertia around the bisector of the OOO angle (bond angle $117^\circ$; OO bond length 128 pm).
results.llm_output:
Here is the step‐by‐step calculation:

1. Molecular geometry  
 Ozone is a symmetric bent triatomic. Let the central O be at the origin, the two terminal O’s at distance  
 r = 128 pm = 1.28×10⁻¹⁰ m  
 and angle ∠OOO = θ = 117°.  
 Half‐angle α = θ/2 = 58.5°.

2. Moment of inertia about the bisector axis through the center of mass  
 Because all three atoms have the same mass m = 16 u = 16·1.66054×10⁻²⁷ kg, the center of mass lies along the bisector, but the perpendicular distances of the two terminal atoms from the bisector are both r sin α, while the central atom lies on the axis and contributes zero. Hence  
 I = 2 m (r sin α)²  
   = 2·(16·1.66054×10⁻²⁷ kg)·(1.28×10⁻¹⁰ m · sin 58.5°)²  
   ≃ 6.32×10⁻⁴⁶ kg·m².

3. Rotational constant in cm⁻¹  
 B = ℎ / (8 π² c I)  
 with ℎ = 6.62607015×10⁻³⁴ J·s, c = 2.99792458×10¹⁰ cm/s.  
 Numerically,  
 8 π² c I ≃ 1.498×10⁻³³  
 ⇒ B ≃ (6.626×10⁻³⁴) / (1.498×10⁻³³) = 0.4426 cm⁻¹.

Final answer:  
\[
\boxed{0.443}\;\text{cm}^{-1}
\]

results.question: A proton jumps between two sites with \(\delta = 2.7\) and \(\delta = 4.8\). What rate constant for the interconversion process is needed for the two signals to collapse to a single line in a spectrometer operating at 550 MHz? **Requirement**: Round the results to one decimal place.
results.llm_output:
Step 1: Compute the difference in chemical shift, Δδ, in ppm  
Δδ = 4.8 ppm − 2.7 ppm = 2.1 ppm  

Step 2: Convert Δδ to a frequency difference Δν in Hz on a 550 MHz spectrometer  
Δν = Δδ·ν₀ = 2.1 ppm × 550 MHz = 2.1 × 550 Hz = 1155 Hz  

Step 3: At coalescence the exchange rate kₙ equals  
 k_c = π Δν / (2 √2)  

Plugging in Δν = 1155 Hz:  
 k_c = π·1155 Hz / (2√2)  
  = (3.14159265 × 1155)/(2 × 1.41421356) s⁻¹  
  ≈ 1282.7 s⁻¹  

Rounded to one decimal place:  

Final answer:  
\[
\boxed{1282.7}
\]\;s⁻¹

results.question: Two groups of protons have \(\delta = 4.0\) and \(\delta = 5.2\) and are interconverted by a conformational change of a fluxional molecule. In a 60 MHz spectrometer the spectrum collapsed into a single line at 280 K but at 300 MHz the collapse did not occur until the temperature had been raised to 300 K. Calculate the exchange rate constant at the two temperatures and hence find the activation energy of the interconversion. Please return the sum as the final answer.
results.llm_output:
Step 1.  Compute the frequency separation in Hz:  
Δδ=5.2–4.0=1.2 ppm.  
At 60 MHz: Δν₁=1.2×60 MHz=72 Hz.  
At 300 MHz: Δν₂=1.2×300 MHz=360 Hz.  

Step 2.  At coalescence for a two‐site exchange of equal populations  
k_c=πΔν/(2√2).  

Thus at T₁=280 K (60 MHz collapse):  
k₁=π·72/(2√2)=72·π/2.8284≈80.1 s⁻¹.  

At T₂=300 K (300 MHz collapse):  
k₂=π·360/(2√2)=360·π/2.8284≈400.5 s⁻¹.  

Step 3.  Use the Arrhenius form (or equivalently the two‐point form of the Eyring equation)  
ln(k₂/k₁)=Ea/R·(1/T₁–1/T₂)  
⇒ Ea=R·ln(k₂/k₁)/(1/T₁–1/T₂).  

With R=8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹, ln(400.5/80.1)=ln5.00=1.609,  
1/280–1/300=(300–280)/(280·300)=20/84000=2.38095×10⁻⁴ K⁻¹,  

Ea=8.314·1.609 / (2.38095×10⁻⁴)=5.62×10⁴ J mol⁻¹=56.2 kJ mol⁻¹.  

Final Answer:  
\boxed{80.1,\ 400.5,\ 56.2}\ s^{-1},\ s^{-1},\ kJ\,mol^{-1}

results.question: The bond length of \(\ce{O2}\) is 120.75 pm. Use the high-temperature approximation to calculate the rotational partition function of the molecule at 300 K
results.llm_output:
Here are the steps to compute the high‐temperature rotational partition function of \(\mathrm{O_2}\) at \(T=300\ \mathrm K\):

1. Convert the bond length to meters:  
   \(r = 120.75\ \mathrm{pm} = 1.2075\times10^{-10}\ \mathrm m.\)

2. Compute the mass of one \(\mathrm{O}\) atom in kg:  
   \(m_{\mathrm O}=16\,u=16\times1.66054\times10^{-27}=2.65686\times10^{-26}\ \mathrm{kg}.\)

3. For a homonuclear diatomic, the reduced mass is  
   \(\displaystyle\mu=\frac{m_{\mathrm O}}2=1.32843\times10^{-26}\ \mathrm{kg}.\)

4. The moment of inertia is  
   \(\displaystyle I=\mu r^2
     =1.32843\times10^{-26}\,(1.2075\times10^{-10})^2
     =1.9379\times10^{-46}\ \mathrm{kg\,m^2}.\)

5. Using the high–temperature approximation for a linear rotor,
   \[
     q_{\rm rot}\approx\frac{T}{\sigma\,\theta_{\rm rot}}
     =\frac{2 I k_B T}{\sigma\,\hbar^2},
   \]
   where \(\sigma=2\) for \(\mathrm{O_2}\).  Noting the factor of 2 in numerator and denominator cancel,
   \[
     q_{\rm rot}
     =\frac{I\,k_B\,T}{\hbar^2}.
   \]

6. Substitute numerical values:
   \(
     k_B=1.380649\times10^{-23}\ \mathrm{J/K},\quad
     \hbar=1.054571817\times10^{-34}\ \mathrm{J\,s},
     \quad T=300\ \mathrm K.
   \)
   Then
   \[
     q_{\rm rot}
     =\frac{(1.9379\times10^{-46})(1.380649\times10^{-23})(300)}
            {(1.054571817\times10^{-34})^2}
     \approx 72.2.
   \)

Final answer:
\[
\boxed{72.2}
\]

results.question: Compute the mean energy at 298 K of a two-level system of energy separation equivalent to 500 cm??.
results.llm_output:
Here is the step‐by‐step calculation:

1.  Convert the wavenumber to SI units:  
    \(\tilde\nu = 500\ \mathrm{cm^{-1}} = 500\times100\ \mathrm{m^{-1}} = 5.00\times10^4\ \mathrm{m^{-1}}\).

2.  Compute the energy gap  
    \[
      \Delta E \;=\; h\,c\,\tilde\nu
      \;=\;(6.62607015\times10^{-34}\,\mathrm{J\,s})
        \,(2.99792458\times10^8\,\mathrm{m/s})
        \,(5.00\times10^4\,\mathrm{m^{-1}})
      \approx 9.9322\times10^{-21}\,\mathrm{J}.
    \]

3.  Compute \(\beta = 1/(k_B T)\) at \(T=298\)\,K:  
    \[
      \beta \;=\;\frac{1}{(1.380649\times10^{-23}\,\mathrm{J/K})(298\,\mathrm{K})}
      \approx 2.426\times10^{20}\,\mathrm{J^{-1}}.
    \]
    Then
    \(\beta\,\Delta E \approx 2.426\times10^{20}\times9.9322\times10^{-21}\approx2.414.\)

4.  The Boltzmann factor and partition function are
    \[
      e^{-\beta\Delta E}\approx e^{-2.414}=0.08949,\qquad
      Z=1+e^{-\beta\Delta E}=1.08949.
    \]

5.  The mean energy is
    \[
      \langle E\rangle
      =\frac{\Delta E\,e^{-\beta\Delta E}}{Z}
      =\frac{9.9322\times10^{-21}\times0.08949}{1.08949}
      \approx8.16\times10^{-22}\,\mathrm{J}.
    \]

Therefore, the mean energy at 298 K is
\[
\boxed{8.16\times10^{-22}}\,\mathrm{J}
\]

Question: """Compute the mean energy at 298 K of a two-level system of energy separation equivalent to 500 cm??."""

Model's reasoning: """Here is the step‐by‐step calculation:

1.  Convert the wavenumber to SI units:  
    \(\tilde\nu = 500\ \mathrm{cm^{-1}} = 500\times100\ \mathrm{m^{-1}} = 5.00\times10^4\ \mathrm{m^{-1}}\).

2.  Compute the energy gap  
    \[
      \Delta E \;=\; h\,c\,\tilde\nu
      \;=\;(6.62607015\times10^{-34}\,\mathrm{J\,s})
        \,(2.99792458\times10^8\,\mathrm{m/s})
        \,(5.00\times10^4\,\mathrm{m^{-1}})
      \approx 9.9322\times10^{-21}\,\mathrm{J}.
    \]

3.  Compute \(\beta = 1/(k_B T)\) at \(T=298\)\,K:  
    \[
      \beta \;=\;\frac{1}{(1.380649\times10^{-23}\,\mathrm{J/K})(298\,\mathrm{K})}
      \approx 2.426\times10^{20}\,\mathrm{J^{-1}}.
    \]
    Then
    \(\beta\,\Delta E \approx 2.426\times10^{20}\times9.9322\times10^{-21}\approx2.414.\)

4.  The Boltzmann factor and partition function are
    \[
      e^{-\beta\Delta E}\approx e^{-2.414}=0.08949,\qquad
      Z=1+e^{-\beta\Delta E}=1.08949.
    \]

5.  The mean energy is
    \[
      \langle E\rangle
      =\frac{\Delta E\,e^{-\beta\Delta E}}{Z}
      =\frac{9.9322\times10^{-21}\times0.08949}{1.08949}
      \approx8.16\times10^{-22}\,\mathrm{J}.
    \]

Therefore, the mean energy at 298 K is
\[
\boxed{8.16\times10^{-22}}\,\mathrm{J}
\]"""

Model's final answer: 8.160000E-22

Correct answer: 8.1500000000000005e-22

Judgement:

results.question: Calculate the standard molar entropy at 298 K of gaseous helium.
results.llm_output:
Below is a calculation using the Sackur–Tetrode equation for a monoatomic ideal gas (standard state $P^\circ=1\,$bar).

1.  Molar mass of He:  
   $M=4.0026\;\mathrm{g\,mol^{-1}}\;\Rightarrow\;m=\dfrac{M}{N_A}
     =\dfrac{4.0026\times10^{-3}}{6.022\times10^{23}}
     =6.646\times10^{-27}\;\mathrm{kg}.$

2.  Constants and conditions:  
   $T=298.15\;\mathrm K,\quad P=1.000\times10^{5}\;\mathrm{Pa},$  
   $k_B=1.380649\times10^{-23}\;\mathrm{J\,K^{-1}},$  
   $h=6.62607015\times10^{-34}\;\mathrm{J\,s},$  
   $R=8.314462618\;\mathrm{J\,K^{-1}mol^{-1}}.$

3.  Sackur–Tetrode formula (per mole):  
   \[
     S_m \;=\; R\Biggl[\ln\Bigl(
       \bigl(2\pi m k_B T/h^2\bigr)^{3/2}\,\frac{k_B T}{P}
     \Bigr)\;+\;\frac{5}{2}\Biggr].
   \]

4.  Evaluate step by step:
   \[
     X = \frac{2\pi m k_B T}{h^2}
       = \frac{2\pi\,(6.646\times10^{-27})(1.38065\times10^{-23})(298.15)}
              {(6.62607\times10^{-34})^2}
       \approx 3.913\times10^{20},
   \]
   \[
     X^{3/2}\approx(3.913\times10^{20})^{1.5}\approx7.743\times10^{30},
     \quad
     \frac{k_B T}{P}=\frac{1.38065\times10^{-23}\times298.15}{1.00\times10^5}
       \approx4.115\times10^{-26},
   \]
   \[
     \ln\Bigl(X^{3/2}\,\frac{k_B T}{P}\Bigr)
     =\ln\bigl(7.743\times10^{30}\times4.115\times10^{-26}\bigr)
     =\ln(3.186\times10^5)\approx12.671,
   \]
   \[
     S_m = R\bigl(12.671 + 2.5\bigr)
         =8.31446\times15.171
         \approx126.2\;\mathrm{J\,K^{-1}mol^{-1}}.
   \]

Final answer:
\[
  \boxed{126.2}\;\mathrm{J\,K^{-1}mol^{-1}}
\]

results.question: Calculate the standard molar entropy at 298 K of gaseous xenon.
results.llm_output:
Step 1:  Start from the Sackur–Tetrode equation for a monatomic ideal gas at pressure \(P\) and temperature \(T\),

\[
S = R\left[\ln\!\Bigl(\frac{k\,T}{P}\,\bigl(\tfrac{2\pi m\,k\,T}{h^2}\bigr)^{3/2}\Bigr) + \frac52\right].
\]

Step 2:  Compute the mass of one Xe atom,
\[
m \;=\;\frac{M}{N_A}
       =\frac{131.293\times10^{-3}\,\mathrm{kg\,mol^{-1}}}{6.02214\times10^{23}\,\mathrm{mol^{-1}}}
       \approx 2.180\times10^{-25}\,\mathrm{kg}.
\]

Step 3:  Evaluate the argument of the logarithm at \(T=298.15\) K, \(P=1.00\times10^5\) Pa:

\[
\frac{kT}{P}\Bigl(\frac{2\pi m kT}{h^2}\Bigr)^{3/2}
=\bigl(4.116\times10^{-26}\bigr)\times\bigl(1.456\times10^{33}\bigr)
\approx5.993\times10^{7},
\]
so
\[
\ln\!\bigl(5.993\times10^{7}\bigr)\approx18.907.
\]

Step 4:  Thus
\[
S = R\bigl[18.907 + 2.5\bigr]
    = 8.3145\times21.407
    \approx178.0\;\mathrm{J\,K^{-1}mol^{-1}}.
\]

Final Answer:

\[
\boxed{178.0}
\] JK-1mol-1

results.question: A \(\ce{CO2}\) molecule is linear, and its vibrational wavenumbers are \(1388.2\ \text{cm}^{-1}\), \(2349.2\ \text{cm}^{-1}\), and \(667.4\ \text{cm}^{-1}\), the last being doubly degenerate and the others non - degenerate. The rotational constant of the molecule is \(0.3902\ \text{cm}^{-1}\). Calculate the rotational contributions to the molar Gibbs energy at 298 K.
results.llm_output:
1.  For a linear rotor, the rotational temperature is  
   \[
     \theta_{\rm rot} = \frac{h c B}{k_B}
     = B\,(hc/k_B)
     = 0.3902\ \mathrm{cm^{-1}}\times1.4388\ \mathrm{cm\cdot K}
     =0.5605\ \mathrm K.
   \]

2.  The symmetry number of CO$_2$ is $\sigma=2$, so the rotational contribution to the molar Gibbs energy is  
   \[
     G_{\rm rot}
     = -R\,T\ln\!\Bigl(\frac{T}{\sigma\,\theta_{\rm rot}}\Bigr).
   \]

3.  At $T=298.15\,$K,  
   \[
     G_{\rm rot}
     = -\bigl(8.31446\ {\rm J\,mol^{-1}K^{-1}}\bigr)\,(298.15\ {\rm K})
       \ln\!\Bigl(\frac{298.15}{2\times0.5605}\Bigr)
     = -1.3840\times10^{4}\ {\rm J\,mol^{-1}}
     = -13.84\ {\rm kJ\,mol^{-1}}.
   \]

4.  Final answer:  
   \[
     \boxed{-13.84}\ \text{kJ mol-1}
   \]

results.question: Calculate the magnitude of the dipole moment of the following arrangement of charges in the \(xy\)-plane: \(3e\) at \((0, 0)\), \(-e\) at \((0.32\ \text{nm}, 0)\), and \(-2e\) at an angle of \(20^\circ\) from the \(x\)-axis and a distance of \(0.23\ \text{nm}\) from the origin.
results.llm_output:
Here “e” is the elementary charge (1.602×10⁻¹⁹ C) and 1 D = 3.336×10⁻³⁰ C·m.

1. Position vectors (in nm):  
   r₁=(0,0),  
   r₂=(0.32,0),  
   r₃=(0.23 cos20°, 0.23 sin20°).

2. Dipole moment  
   p=∑qᵢrᵢ=q₂r₂+q₃r₃  
   =–e·(0.32,0) nm –2e·(0.23 cos20°, 0.23 sin20°) nm  
   =–e·(0.32+0.46 cos20°, 0.46 sin20°) nm.

3. Components:  
   pₓ=–e·(0.32+0.46·0.9397)=–e·0.75226 nm  
   p_y=–e·(0.46·0.3420)=–e·0.15732 nm.

4. Magnitude:  
   |p|=e·√(0.75226²+0.15732²) nm  
       =1.602×10⁻¹⁹ C·(0.76885×10⁻⁹m)  
       =1.231×10⁻²⁸ C·m  
       =1.231×10⁻²⁸/(3.336×10⁻³⁰) D  
       ≈36.9 D.

Therefore the dipole moment is  
\[
\boxed{36.9}\text{ D}
\]

results.question: Calculate the direction of the dipole moment of the following arrangement of charges in the \(xy\)-plane: \(3e\) at \((0, 0)\), \(-e\) at \((0.32\ \text{nm}, 0)\), and \(-2e\) at an angle of \(20^\circ\) from the \(x\)-axis and a distance of \(0.23\ \text{nm}\) from the origin.
results.llm_output:
Step 1: Write the dipole moment vector  
\[
\mathbf p \;=\;\sum_i q_i\,\mathbf r_i
\;=\;3e\,(0,0)\;+\;(-e)\,(0.32,0)\;+\;(-2e)\bigl(0.23\cos20^\circ,\;0.23\sin20^\circ\bigr).
\]

Step 2: Compute the components (in units of e·nm)  
\[
p_x=-e\bigl(0.32+2\cdot0.23\cos20^\circ\bigr)
=-e\;(0.32+0.46\cdot0.9397)
\approx -0.7523\,e,
\]
\[
p_y=-2e\cdot0.23\sin20^\circ
=-e\;(0.46\cdot0.3420)
\approx -0.1573\,e.
\]

Step 3: Find the angle \(\theta\) relative to the +x‐axis  
\[
\tan\theta=\frac{p_y}{p_x}
=\frac{-0.1573}{-0.7523}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\theta=\arctan(0.2091)=11.83^\circ,
\]
but \((p_x,p_y)\) lies in the third quadrant, so
\[
\theta=180^\circ+11.83^\circ=191.83^\circ.
\]

Final Answer:
\[
\boxed{191.8}^\circ
\]

results.question: At \(0\ ^{\circ}\text{C}\), the molar polarization of liquid chlorine trifluoride is \(27.18\ \text{cm}^3\ \text{mol}^{-1}\) and its mass density is \(1.89\ \text{g}\ \text{cm}^{-3}\). Calculate the relative permittivity of the liquid.
results.llm_output:
Step 1: Compute the molar mass of ClF₃  
M(ClF₃)=M(Cl)+3M(F)=35.45+3×18.998=92.44 g mol⁻¹  

Step 2: Compute the molar volume  
Vₘ= M/ρ = 92.44 g mol⁻¹ / (1.89 g cm⁻³) = 48.89 cm³ mol⁻¹  

Step 3: Clausius–Mossotti relation in terms of molar polarization P  
P = \frac{ε_r − 1}{ε_r + 2} Vₘ  
⇒ \frac{ε_r − 1}{ε_r + 2} = \frac{P}{Vₘ} = \frac{27.18}{48.89} = 0.5558  

Step 4: Solve for ε_r  
ε_r−1 = 0.5558(ε_r+2)  
ε_r − 1 = 0.5558ε_r +1.1116  
0.4442 ε_r = 2.1116  
ε_r = 2.1116 / 0.4442 = 4.75  

Final answer:  
\displaystyle \boxed{4.75}

Question: """At \(0\ ^{\circ}\text{C}\), the molar polarization of liquid chlorine trifluoride is \(27.18\ \text{cm}^3\ \text{mol}^{-1}\) and its mass density is \(1.89\ \text{g}\ \text{cm}^{-3}\). Calculate the relative permittivity of the liquid."""

Model's reasoning: """Step 1: Compute the molar mass of ClF₃  
M(ClF₃)=M(Cl)+3M(F)=35.45+3×18.998=92.44 g mol⁻¹  

Step 2: Compute the molar volume  
Vₘ= M/ρ = 92.44 g mol⁻¹ / (1.89 g cm⁻³) = 48.89 cm³ mol⁻¹  

Step 3: Clausius–Mossotti relation in terms of molar polarization P  
P = \frac{ε_r − 1}{ε_r + 2} Vₘ  
⇒ \frac{ε_r − 1}{ε_r + 2} = \frac{P}{Vₘ} = \frac{27.18}{48.89} = 0.5558  

Step 4: Solve for ε_r  
ε_r−1 = 0.5558(ε_r+2)  
ε_r − 1 = 0.5558ε_r +1.1116  
0.4442 ε_r = 2.1116  
ε_r = 2.1116 / 0.4442 = 4.75  

Final answer:  
\displaystyle \boxed{4.75}"""

Model's final answer: 4.75

Correct answer: 4.75

Judgement:

results.question: In an industrial process, nitrogen is heated to 500 K at a constant volume of (1.000\ \text{m}^3). The mass of the gas is 92.4 kg. Use the van der Waals equation to determine the approximate pressure of the gas at its working temperature of 500 K. For nitrogen, (a = 1.352\ \text{dm}^6\ \text{atm}\ \text{mol}^{-2}), (b = 0.0387\ \text{dm}^3\ \text{mol}^{-1}).
results.llm_output:
Step 1:  Compute the number of moles of N₂.  
Molar mass of N₂: M = 28.02 g·mol⁻¹.  
Mass m = 92.4 kg = 9.24×10⁴ g.  
⇒ n = m/M = (9.24×10⁴ g)/(28.02 g·mol⁻¹) ≃ 3.298×10³ mol.  

Step 2:  Convert volume to dm³ (1 m³ = 10³ dm³):  
V = 1.000 m³ = 1000 dm³.  

Step 3:  van der Waals equation in the form  
 P = nRT/(V – nb) – a(n/V)².  

Parameters (in dm³, atm, mol, K):  
R = 0.082057 dm³·atm·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹,  
T = 500 K,  
a = 1.352 dm⁶·atm·mol⁻²,  
b = 0.0387 dm³·mol⁻¹.  

Compute each term:  
nRT = (3.298×10³ mol)(0.082057 dm³·atm·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹)(500 K) ≃ 1.3531×10⁵ dm³·atm,  
V – nb = 1000 dm³ – (3.298×10³ mol)(0.0387 dm³·mol⁻¹) ≃ 8.7237×10² dm³,  
⇒ nRT/(V – nb) ≃ (1.3531×10⁵)/(8.7237×10²) ≃ 155.2 atm,  
a(n/V)² = 1.352×(3.298 mol·dm⁻³)² ≃ 14.7 atm.  

Hence  
P ≃ 155.2 atm – 14.7 atm = 140.5 atm.  

Final answer:  
\[
\boxed{140.5}
\]\,atm

results.question: What pressure would 4.56 g of nitrogen gas in a vessel of volume (2.25\ \text{dm}^3) exert at 273 K if it obeyed the virial equation of state up to and including the first two terms?
results.llm_output:
Here’s the calculation step by step:

1.  Moles of N₂  
   n = mass/M = (4.56 g)/(28.02 g mol⁻¹) = 0.1627 mol  

2.  Convert volume to litres  
   V = 2.25 dm³ = 2.25 L  

3.  Use the virial equation to first order:  
   P V = nRT (1 + B/Vₘ)  
   where Vₘ = V/n is the molar volume, so equivalently  
   P = (nRT/V) (1 + B n/V)  

4.  Take the second virial coefficient for N₂ at 273 K (from tables)  
   B = –0.0217 L mol⁻¹  

5.  Compute  
   nRT/V = (0.1627 mol)(0.08206 L atm mol⁻¹ K⁻¹)(273 K)/(2.25 L)  
            = 1.6206 atm  
   Correction factor = 1 + (B n/V)  
                     = 1 + [–0.0217 L mol⁻¹ × 0.1627 mol / 2.25 L]  
                     = 0.99843  
   ⇒ P = 1.6206 atm × 0.99843  
       ≈ 1.62 atm  

Final answer:  
\[
\boxed{1.62}
\] atm

results.question: Assume that \pu{1 L} of E10 fuel contains \pu{100 mL} of ethanol and \pu{900 mL} of octane isomers, and that \pu{1 L} of E5 fuel contains \pu{50 mL} of ethanol and \pu{950 mL} of octane isomers. Taking the \ce{CO2} produced from burning \pu{1 L} of E5 fuel as \pu{100 %}, what is the percentage of \ce{CO2} produced from burning \pu{1 L} of E10 fuel. Consider only \ce{CO2} formed from the combustion of octane isomers?
results.llm_output:
Step 1: Note that we only consider the CO₂ from octane.  
– In E5 fuel: V₁ = 950 mL octane ⇒ CO₂₁ ≡ 100%  
– In E10 fuel: V₂ = 900 mL octane ⇒ CO₂₂ = ?  

Step 2: CO₂₂ scales with octane volume, so  
CO₂₂/CO₂₁ = V₂/V₁ = 900 mL / 950 mL  

Step 3: Hence  
CO₂₂ = 100% × (900/950) = (900/950)·100% ≈ 94.74%  

Final answer:  
\boxed{94.74}\%

results.question: A methane flame of \pu{2.5 mm} height is observed above the bunsen burner whose tube has a diameter of \pu{8 mm}.  The laminar flame speed at \pu{25 deg C}, \pu{101.325 kPa} and air to fuel equivalence ratio ($\lambda$) of 1.2 is \pu{0.38 m/s}. What would be the air flow rate (\pu{L/min}) if reactants enter the burner at \pu{25 deg C}, \pu{101.325 kPa} and air to fuel equivalence ratio ($\lambda$) of 1.2?
results.llm_output:
Step 1: geometry of the flame cone  
The flame has height \(H=2.5\)\,mm and base radius \(R=D/2=4\)\,mm, so the half‐angle \(\alpha\) of the cone satisfies  
\[
\tan\alpha=\frac{R}{H}=\frac{4}{2.5}\,,\quad
\alpha=\arctan(1.6)\approx58.0^\circ\,.
\]

Step 2: relate axial flow speed \(U\) to laminar flame speed \(S_L\)  
Burning velocity is normal to the flame surface, so  
\[
S_L \;=\; U\cos\alpha
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
U=\frac{S_L}{\cos\alpha}
=\frac{0.38\rm\ m/s}{\cos58^\circ}
\approx0.718\rm\ m/s\,.
\]

Step 3: total mixture volumetric flow rate  
Burner cross‐sectional area \(A=\pi D^2/4=\pi(0.008)^2/4\approx5.027\times10^{-5}\rm\ m^2\).  
Thus
\[
Q_{\rm mix}
=U\,A
=0.718\;\frac{\rm m}{\rm s}\times5.027\times10^{-5}\;\rm m^2
\approx3.61\times10^{-5}\;\frac{\rm m^3}{\rm s}
=2.17\;\rm L/min\,.
\]

Step 4: fraction of that which is air at \(\lambda=1.2\)  
Stoichiometric \(\rm CH_4+2O_2\) in air (\(21\%\) O₂ by vol) needs
\[
AF_{st}=\frac{2}{0.21}\approx9.524\;\text{vol air per vol fuel.}
\]
At \(\lambda=1.2\), vol air/vol fuel \(=1.2\times9.524=11.43\), so air is
\(\tfrac{11.43}{1+11.43}=0.9196\) of the total mixture volume.  Hence
\[
Q_{\rm air}
=0.9196\times2.17\;\rm L/min
\approx1.99\;\rm L/min\,.
\]

Final answer:
\[
\boxed{1.99}\;{\rm L/min}
\]
